body: Thank you @bpgergo. LGTM. I will merge this. Please open a new PR for the Python examples.
LGTM
For reference, this was correctly merged but somehow github put this weird unmerged commits message.

https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2679 and
https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2727, plus a third change for list,
set, nullable, union, CoGbkResult coders are authored and will come along
with a worker change, which will provide a stable version prior to the
runner API. Runner-API serialized coders and CloudObject serialized coders
cannot be update-compatible.

On Fri, Apr 28, 2017 at 6:56 AM, reuvenlax <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> Any comment on what we are doing for now?
>
>
> On Tue, Apr 25, 2017 at 4:09 PM, Reuven Lax <relax@google.com> wrote:
>
> > Coders can provide an encoding id (Coder.getEncodingId) which can be used
> > along with the class name to identify a Coder. As far as I can tell, none
> > of our coders currently use this.
> >
> > On Tue, Apr 25, 2017 at 3:59 PM, Lukasz Cwik <notifications@github.com>
> > wrote:
> >
> >> The plan is to drop the usage of Jackson as the payload format which was
> >> convenient when adding to CloudObject and instead allow coders to
> provide
> >> converters from Java/Python Coder -> Beam Runner API Coder (proto). This
> >> would allow for Coders to define and maintain a stable format. Is there
> a
> >> concern if this work to finish the Coder -> Beam Runner API Coder
> (proto)
> >> occurs after first stable release?
> >>
> >> On Tue, Apr 25, 2017 at 3:48 PM, reuvenlax <notifications@github.com>
> >> wrote:
> >>
> >> > In the past we've avoided using CustomCoder for most core coders due
> to
> >> > it's use of Java Serializable. The Dataflow runner supports updating a
> >> > running pipeline, and will fail the update if the coder appears to
> >> change.
> >> > Using Serializable to define the coder makes it very susceptible to
> >> change
> >> > on otherwise innocuous updates.
> >> >

Infra has removed the travis webhook, so we're good to go on that front.

HDFSFileSource/HDFSFileSink is to be deprecated and being replaced with a HadoopFileSystem which can be used with all file based sources and sinks like TextIO, AvroIO, etc...

Once #2762 is merged, please rebase on top of apache/master and add your logic to the ConfigurationLocator found within HadoopFileSystemOptions:
https://github.com/apache/beam/pull/2762/files#diff-6365d505a27aadc172e5efde96e6e541

There is still value Travis CI provides for python as that is the only way we can test installation on mac. Is it possible to just keep the Python tests around and remove all things related to Java.

cc @aaltay

R: @vikkyrk @tgroh @dhalperi
#2675 also solves this

I agree with @sb2nov. Python tests in Travis is green, and it is providing an especially valuable signal with macos tests. Until we can have macos coverage in other forms, I am in favor of keeping python tests in Travis.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11294135/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11294135)

Coverage decreased (-0.0003%) to 69.684% when pulling **4e1441657630e15868dd9602dcbf7c59df9f8f80 on reuvenlax:per_table_schemas** into **47aaf11250e61d61c0bb3616063dbd5b7f2adb88 on apache:master**.
Thanks.

It's not so simple as that. Travis could possibly be used to test "a little" -- this feature or that feature of the project, but it cannot test the project. How could we justify testing one component and not the other?

Then, Travis is not nearly as configurable as Jenkins, and really doesn't align with the future growth of the project.

MacOS signal, indeed, is valuable, but that's the only pro -- everything else are cons that are really hard to justify.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11294533/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11294533)

Coverage increased (+0.001%) to 69.685% when pulling **c2320d500c2239ae288ed3f8258a4b3f742e53ed on dhalperi:isDirectory** into **a8a04a2905e1ff639f403be7d9132acb77365e84 on apache:master**.

I don't understand that argument completely though. It is not like Travis is stopping us from running tests for other parts on Jenkins. 

The main reason we faced issues with Travis was that our tests took longer than an hour in contrast python tests finish in about 10 mins have generally been pretty stable on Travis as well. So if it can help with development in certain parts of the project I fail to see the rational that we shouldn't use it.

I think one way to think about it could be that we don't have a CI system, we just have a suite of CI systems where we prefer Jenkins whenever possible but shouldn't discard others if they can provide some value.

LGTM. Definitely an improvement and unblocks things. Merging.

Nearly every component we have finishes tests within the 10 minute mark when executed alone. The thing is that we have so many components. How could we justify testing one component and not the other?

"Some value" is not enough, because there's a cost involved too. All contributors will have to wait for the signal to come back, someone has to maintain the infrastructure around it, cognitive load, etc.
LGTM (lemme know if I should merge)

Please merge

Coverage increased (+0.002%) to 69.685% when pulling **840c8e761a0902f32022d0ea360831c7d020cacc on vikkyrk:ioc_ITs** into **f9406c76657e7dc6cd094b1e7281242e3f5fc9e9 on apache:master**.

I don't think the technical portrayal of Travis is accurate here. We did hit some actual issues (a bit improved now with auto cancelation) but we were trying to use a wrench to hammer a nail. It is easy to use Travis in a way so that you have ~zero cost for a little benefit. It doesn't need to scale if you don't try to do everything. I view our failure to benefit from Travis as almost entirely our fault.

This discussion and decision about whether and how we choose to utilize the tool do not belong on a PR. I started this PR just to mitigate the Jenkins outage; now we don't have that option without flipping it back on anyhow so I am just going to close the PR.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11296390/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11296390)

Coverage decreased (-0.007%) to 69.676% when pulling **fb3ae18a2707575bcd206720e9fcb7b3be3a60dd on meunierd:BEAM-2114** into **f9406c76657e7dc6cd094b1e7281242e3f5fc9e9 on apache:master**.

@aljoscha SDF code does not inspect watermarks, it only sets watermark holds. For further debugging I'd recommend to add some instrumentation in OutputAndTimeBoundedSplittableProcessElementInvoker, as well as in the fn under test itself.

It is expected, in this test, with default settings of that invoker (which I don't think Flink changes), that it will output up to 12344 in one invocation of ProcessElement, and output the rest in subsequent invocations. If it's getting stalled, that means the continuation is not getting scheduled - e.g. perhaps because the watermark hold didn't get set or got lost, and Flink simply dropped the continuation as "late data".
See also ProcessFn.processElement which sets the watermark holds.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11296801/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11296801)

R: @tgroh

LGTM.

(https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-2121 for adding macos testing on Jenkins)
Nice.
#2762 has been merged.
That order does seem sensible. It all comes from whether we consider the coder registry to be carefully curated by a user, in which case it should still have precedence.
@robertwb PTAL
I think the order of (1) use non-fallbacks in the registry then (2) use the transform's coder and then (3) use fallback. 1 and 3 are basically orthogonal.
But really if someone went to the trouble to implement `getDefaultOutputCoder` they probably know best. So this change also LGTM, it is just a change in the intent and I wanted to note that.
self-merge at will.
R: @davorbonaci @dhalperi

In particular, "failure to benefit from Travis" doesn't at all hold from Python's perspective, especially with the recent (ongoing? looks like the most recent build was 4 hours ago) Jenkins outages. 

At the very least, it can provide a smoke signal while jenkins is down and/or slow. Say, testing Python + Java Core. 

FWIW, I looked for an on-list discussion of this decision to remove travis, and didn't see one.

Yes. Also, the registry is pipeline-level, getDefaultOutputCoder is
scoped (and overridden) at a transform level, and finally setCoder()
is per-instance. Note that many transforms (in particular those with
type parameters) still re-invoke the coder registry (but with more
context than we have here).

I'll ensure all tests pass (hopefully jenkins is back up and running
again soon, looks like it's not taking any more builds right now).

run dataflow validatesrunner

The community had a discussion looong ago -- with Jenkins being our preferred solution and Travis-CI being a temporary patch. In fact, folks have been working on unification for a while now. With the aggregate Travis signal being broken for *months* now and nobody stepping in to fix it, it certainly seems like the right kind of clean up.
R: @kennknowles @lukecwik (either)

Since Jenkins is down, I have run the Dataflow ValidatesRunner tests that pertain to `OutputTimeFn` specifically. All pipelines use it, so basic coverage is guaranteed, and `GroupByKeyTest` and `WindowingTest` ensure the changes needed to use a `TimestampCombiner` instead are made.
LGTM, though there are a lot more places in the SDK where we don't use this technique. I'd say it should be only temporary.
I'll wait for Robert's LGTM.
Just noting the alternative of leaving the methods and heavily documenting that they are internal only, which is what we've done most places.
OK, since coders with payloads currently use a different code path, and this helps trim the SDK quickly, LGTM. We can solve the payload problem later and evolve this so that it is unified.
R: @dhalperi
R: @davorbonaci @dhalperi

This PR doesn't appear to touch the FileBasedSink base class.
